title: Helena Bonham Carter talked to Princess Margaret's friends when filming The Crown
text:
Helena Bonham Carter has revealed how she approached Princess Margaret's inside circle for help in understanding the royal's character, as she prepared for her role in Netflix drama The Crown.

The British actress, 53, who has taken over from Vanessa Kirby's portrayal of the royal for series three and four of the hit series, told how she learned that the Queen's younger sister had an 'inability to feign'.

According to her friends, Margaret, who passed away in 2002 aged 71, would say 'whatever popped into her mouth', making her a 'time bomb'.

Helena Bonham Carter (seen in New York in 2018) has revealed how she approached Princess Margaret's inside circle for help in understanding the royal's character as she prepared for her role in Netflix drama The Crown

Speaking to Ok! magazine, she revealed how she researched the role by speaking to Margaret's friends, adding: 'They loved the woman and were very happy to talk about her because they miss her.'

Speaking of what she learned about her character, Helena continued: 'She just couldn't feign, which is an appalling lack when you are famous and you have to meet all these people.

'Whatever was in her head popped out of her mouth. She was like a time bomb'.

Helena recently recalled meeting Princess Margaret, explaining that her uncle, Liberal MP Mark Bonham Carter was close to the royal.

'She was pretty scary,' admitted the actress. 'At one point, she met me at Windsor Castle and she said, "You are getting better, aren’t you?”', presumably referring to her acting skills.

Helena is taking over the role of Princess Margaret for series three and four of Netflix hit The Crown, after Vanessa Kirby's acclaimed portrayal for the first two series.

As the drama moves through 1964 to 1978, Ben Daniels takes over from Matthew Goode in the role of Margaret's husband Antony Armstrong-Jones.

The show's creator Morgan has moved on from the marital drama between the show's leads Queen Elizabeth, played by Olivia Colman in the third series who follows Claire Foy, and Tobias Menzies' Prince Philip, who was previously played by Matt Smith.

Instead, the new episodes will follow the unravelling of Margaret's tumultuous relationship.

Helena, Olivia, Ben and Tobias will star in the third and fourth series of The Crown, which hits screens on 17 November, joined by an older Prince Charles played by Bafta nominee Josh O’Connor and Emerald Fennell as Camilla.
